chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should ensure that everyone can access essential primary, preventive, mental health, and emergency care without facing medical bankruptcy, while allowing people to choose supplemental private coverage if they want more options. To make universal access sustainable, it should set clear coverage standards, negotiate or cap excessive prices where markets fail, reduce administrative waste, and fund help for lower-income families through targeted subsidies. Delivery can remain pluralistic—public, nonprofit, and private providers—so long as outcomes, transparency, and accountability are enforced.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee a universal, affordable baseline of preventive, primary, mental health, and catastrophic coverage so no one faces medical bankruptcy and families and small businesses can stay stable. To keep costs sustainable, it should set clear standards, enforce price transparency and strong cost controls, and simplify administration with strict fiscal accountability. Private plans and providers can continue to compete and innovate above that floor, with portable coverage and community-based partnerships that preserve patient choice and improve access locally.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should ensure that every American can get basic, timely care—primary, preventive, mental health, and protection from catastrophic bills—so no family or small business is pushed into bankruptcy by illness. It should set clear national standards, improve price transparency, reduce administrative waste, and target subsidies to those who need help, while allowing regulated private plans and employer options to compete and offer supplemental coverage. Delivery should rely on local clinicians and community providers, with strong anti-fraud enforcement and fiscal accountability so taxpayers see measurable value.
